Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of painted rock art on a sandstone rock face, showing one cow figure, upright and facing left, painted and infilled in bichrome brown and white, with naturalistic coat pattern markings and with white, u-shaped horns. The cow has three vertical white ‘bar’ markings on the neck and one across the muzzle (collar? Halter?). To the left is the head and shoulder of another, upright, facing right and infilled in brown and cut off the edge of the image at the shoulder. At bottom left is the head of a cow with similar orientation, infilled in white with short, white, backward- sweeping horns and cut off the edge of the image at the shoulder. Magharat el-Kantara, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: Detail of 2013,2034.81. Magharat el-Kantara is a cave where an overhang forms a low rock shelter. It is located on a promontory separating the Wadi Firaq from the Wadi Wassa in the southern part of the the Gilf Kebir plateau in south-west Egypt. It is the only known rock art site in the south-eastern part of Gilf Kebir. The cave and its cattle paintings were discovered by a member of an expedition led by W.B.K. Shaw in 1935, the account of which was published in Antiquity. It was later investigated by Giancarlo Negro and Yves Gauthier in 1997.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
